metadata.titleEn: Multi-scale surface flux and meteorological elements observation dataset in the Hai River Basin (Daxing site-automatic weather station) (2008-2010)
metadata.description:
The data set contains observations from the automatic weather station as of 31 December 2010 as of 1 solstice January 2008.The station is located in weishanzhuang, daxing district, Beijing.The latitude and longitude of the observation point are 116.4271E, 39.6213N and 20m above sea level.
The acquisition frequency of the automatic weather station is 10s, and the output of 10min is once.The observation factors include air temperature and relative humidity (10m), and the direction is due to the north.Wind speed (27m), wind direction (27m), heading due north;Air pressure (installed in waterproof box);Rainfall (30m);Four - component radiation (28m), the direction is due to the south;Infrared surface temperature (28m), the arm is facing south, the probe is facing vertically downward;The soil temperature and humidity probe was buried 2m south of the meteorological tower. The buried depth of the soil temperature probe was 2cm, 5cm, 10cm, 20cm, 40cm, 60cm, 80cm and 100cm. The buried depth of the soil water sensor was 2cm, 5cm, 10cm, 20cm, 40cm, 40cm, 60cm and 100cm.Two soil hot plates (2) were buried 2cm underground, one under the vegetation and the other between the trees.Processing and quality control of observation data :(1) ensure 144 data per day (every 10min). If data is missing, it will be marked by -6999;(2) eliminate the moments with duplicate records;(3) data that is obviously beyond the physical meaning or the range of the instrument is deleted;(4) the format of date and time is unified, and the date and time are in the same column.For example, the time is: June 10, 2010 at 10:30.
Data released by the automatic weather station include:Date/Time, air temperature and humidity observation (Ta_10m, RH_10m) (℃, %), wind speed (Ws_27m) (m/s), wind direction (WD_27m) (°), pressure (Press) (hpa), precipitation (Rain) (mm), four-component radiation (DR, UR, DLR_Cor, ULR_Cor, Rn) (W/m2), surface radiation temperature (IRT_1, IRT_2) (℃),Soil heat flux (Gs_1, Gs_2) (W/m2), multi-layer soil moisture (Ms_2cm, Ms_5cm, Ms_10cm, Ms_20cm, Ms_40cm, Ms_60cm, Ms_100cm) (%) and multi-layer soil temperature (Ts_2cm, Ts_5cm, Ts_10cm, Ts_20cm, Ts_40cm, Ts_60cm, Ts_80cm, Ts_100cm) (℃).
Please refer to Jia et al,(2012) for information of observation test or site, and Liu et al,(2013) for data processing.

background: The accurate estimation of water and heat fluxes is crucial to climate change research, water resource planning and management, and water-saving agriculture applications. Ground measurements are relatively accurate at the patch scale. However, the monitoring network for ground measurements is not sufficient for global coverage, and there is a need to upscale observations from the patch to the regional scale. The remote sensing method can acquire land surface information accurately at the regional scale, which creates new opportunities for monitoring water and heat fluxes. Over the last 20 years, evolving land surface models have been able to produce continuous temporal and spatial variations of water and heat fluxes. However, the land model output is strongly contaminated by uncertainties within the model parameters, model structures, and forcing data; this has adversely affected the development and application of land surface models. Considering these issues, developing a series of techniques combining land surface models with different types of observations is necessary. Data assimilation is one such technique and is one of the most advanced approaches to improving land surface model predictions. Surface temperature has been established to be a key factor for water and energy balance studies. Surface temperature influences the partitioning of incoming radiant energy into ground, as well as sensible and latent heat fluxes. Overestimating the surface temperature results in excessive estimates of sensible and soil heat fluxes, which can impact the boundary layer development and atmospheric dynamics. Underestimating the results has corresponding adverse effects. Although latent heat flux is mainly affected by soil moisture, surface temperature is an important parameter too.
research objective: This study developed two data assimilation strategies that combine the MODIS LST products with the Common Land Model (CLM). Strategy 1 improves water and heat flux estimates by adjusting soil temperature, while strategy 2 achieves this goal by adjusting soil moisture.
challenges: The monitoring network for ground measurements is not sufficient for global coverage, and there is a need to upscale observations from the patch to the regional scale. Overestimating the surface temperature results in excessive estimates of sensible and soil heat fluxes, which can impact the boundary layer development and atmospheric dynamics. Underestimating the results has corresponding adverse effects. The land model output is strongly contaminated by uncertainties within the model parameters, model structures, and forcing data; this has adversely affected the development and application of land surface models.
methods: The developed data assimilation system consists of a model operator for calculating the diurnal variations in water and heat fluxes, an observation operator for predicting surface temperature from model state variables, and an optimization scheme for optimizing the state variables, all of which are described below. In this study, two data assimilation strategies were developed to assimilate the MODIS LST products. Strategy 1 improves the estimation of water and heat fluxes by adjusting soil temperature, while strategy 2 adjusts the soil moisture. In this study, two different optimization algorithms were applied for the two strategies: the EnKF and SCE-UA.
dataset: The assimilation results were validated at six observation sites with different land cover types (grassland, cropland, and orchard) located in Germany, the United States, and China.
findings: Overall, the two strategies improved the estimates of surface temperature and water and heat fluxes by adjusting the soil temperature and moisture, respectively. Strategy 2 was superior to strategy 1 when using the same optimization algorithm. The EnKF algorithm performed slightly better than the SCE-UA algorithm when using the same strategy. Strategy 2 combined with the EnKF algorithm performed best for water and heat fluxes, and the reductions in RMSE values were 24.0 and 15.2 W m22 for the sensible and latent heat fluxes, respectively. For the results at the six experiment sites, the combination of strategy 2 with the EnKF algorithm achieved the most significant reductions in RMSE values. For surface temperature, the most significant reduction in the RMSE value was 4.0 K at the GuanTao site. The sensible heat flux had the most significant reduction in its RMSE value of 48.1 W m22 at the GuanTao site, and latent heat flux reduction was 27.8 W m22 at the Goodwin site.

background: Aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is a key factor in surface flux estimations with remote sensing algorithms and/or land surface models. Originally, z0m is defined as the height where the wind speed, given by the extrapolation of the logarithmic wind profile, becomes zero. According to numerous observations, the variation range of z0m over different surfaces is large, from an order of 1.0 m over urban areas and mountainous areas, to an order of 0.1 mm or even 0.01 mm over smooth water body surfaces, ice and snow surfaces. The traditional way to calculate z0m is based on the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory, using wind profile measurements. In practical applications, especially for remote sensing models and land surface models, it is difficult to obtain z0m for a local or regional scale based only on station observations. Former researchers have proposed some parameterizations between the aerodynamic roughness length and the land surface properties [e.g., vegetation height, leaf area index (LAI), etc.], since wind turbulence is controlled by the structure and spacing of roughness elements (plants and other obstacles) on the land surface, and z0m describes the roughness characteristics of a surface.
research objective: Based on the data of the Xiaotangshan Experiment (Changping District of Beijing, China), which was conducted in 2002, 2004, and 2005 respectively, the objectives of this paper are: (1) to calculate z0m over different surfaces and analyze the directional characteristics of z0m over heterogeneous surfaces using an analytical footprint model; (2) to relate the estimated z0m over heterogeneous surfaces to roughness element characteristic factors, and present a heuristic parameterization of z0m as a reference for model parameterizations.
challenges: More data is needed for further discussions.
methods: This paper calculates z0m over several land surfaces, with 3 years of experimental data from Xiaotangshan. Individual z0m over each surface component (patch) is calculated firstly with the characteristic parameters of the roughness elements (vegetation height, leaf area index, etc.), then z0m over the whole experimental field is aggregated, using the footprint weighting method.
dataset: This experiment was carried out at the Xiaotangshan Experimental Station for Precision Agriculture (40°10′41′′N, 116°26′52′′E, 35 m above sea level) in Beijing. The observation period in 2002 was from 26 March to 23 April and the land cover was bare soil. In 2004, the experiment was carried out from 30 May to 7 July. In the southern sub-plot field, the land cover was bare soil between 30 May and 11 June, while the maize plants started emerging around 12 June. In 2005, the experiment was from 1 May to 10 June and the experimental layout was almost the same as that in 2004.
findings: The results show that z0m is direction-dependent, mainly due to the heterogeneity of the size and spatial distribution of the roughness elements inside the source area along different wind directions.

background: Sensible and latent heat fluxes are important indicators reflecting the intensity of heat and water vapor exchange between the land and atmosphere, influencing the energy balance between them, providing material, dynamic, and thermal sources for weather systems of different scales, and affecting the water cycle process between the land and atmosphere. Currently, there are many traditional methods for observing surface fluxes, such as the Eddy-Covariance system (EC), Bowen ratio-energy balance system, and aerodynamic methods. Among these, the Eddy-Covariance system is internationally recognized as the most reliable method for observing surface fluxes; however, its observation scale is relatively small, with spatial representativeness only in the range of tens to hundreds of meters. The Large Aperture Scintillometer (LAS), in contrast to traditional Eddy-Covariance systems, can obtain average sensible heat fluxes at a regional scale (from hundreds of meters to several kilometers). Because the observation scale of LAS aligns well with satellite pixel scales and the grid scales of numerical weather prediction and climate models, the observations from LAS can serve as ground truth at the pixel/grid scale for remote sensing estimation models, numerical weather prediction models, and climate models, thereby optimizing and validating these models. The observation principle of LAS is based on the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST), which, combined with the observed atmospheric refractive index structure parameter C2n and related meteorological data, utilizes the stability universal function fT related to the temperature structure parameter C2T to obtain the regional average sensible heat flux at the surface.
research objective: Using the LAS-related data from Guantao Station (January to December 2009) and Arou Station (January to June and October to November), the applicability of the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) in LAS observations was analyzed, and a quantitative assessment method for the applicability of MOST was explored.
challenges: Due to the influence of underlying surface cover types, flatness, water and thermal conditions, and weather conditions, it is difficult to achieve the ideal assumption of uniformity in practice. Currently, domestic research on atmospheric similarity theory mainly focuses on the similarity relationships of wind, temperature profiles, and turbulence variance. However, there is relatively little research on the similarity between temperature structure parameters and turbulence characteristics in scintillation methods.
methods: Before analyzing the applicability of the MOST theory to LAS data, preliminary processing of EC and LAS data is conducted. LAS, EC, and AWS data from the Guantao Station for the year 2009 (January to December) and from the Aru Station (January to June and October to November) are selected.
dataset:
Guantao Station (36°30′54″N, 115°07′39″E) is located in Hezhai Village, Guantao County, Hebei Province. Its observation site and the surrounding underlying surface consist of farmland, including winter wheat, corn, and cotton, with winter wheat and corn being rotated. The growth period for winter wheat is from October to June of the following year, while the growth period for corn is from June to October, and for cotton, it is from May to October. This area represents a typical farmland underlying surface of the North China Plain. In the LAS source area, the area of winter wheat (corn) accounts for about 45%, and cotton accounts for about 47%. 

Arou Station (38°02′40″N, 100°27′53″E) is located in the valley area upstream of the Heihe River, and its observation site and surrounding underlying surface consist of typical alpine grassland, which is relatively flat. The vegetation height in the source area can reach 0.2 to 0.3 meters during the growing season.
findings: (1) Under unstable conditions, large-scale vortex motion, atmospheric turbulence development, and temperature scales can significantly affect the applicability of the MOST theory; (2) Two new methods for assessing the applicability of the MOST theory have been established, namely factor analysis and temperature structure parameter methods, and it has been verified that these two assessment methods are reasonable and reliable.

background: For surface flux measurements, large aperture scintillometer (LAS) has become more and more popular in recent years. Compared with traditional observation techniques, it can measure surface fluxes on a larger scale (500 m to 10 km). At present, LAS observation is not common in China.
research objective: The daily and monthly variation of HLAS is analyzed. And the observation differences between eddy covariance system and LAS, need to be studied further combined with footprint model and energy unbalance of eddy covariance system observation.
challenges: There is much less agreement on the form which universal stability function fT should take. Further more, since the iteration process of HLAS can not be convergence when low wind speed and very stable conditions appearing at night, Wm \ - 5 is specified.
findings: Sensible heat flux (H) calculation with the LAS data of above measurements shows that the beam height of LAS and wind speed are sensitive factors for sensible heat flux measurement (HLAS), zero-plane displacement height is crucial unless the beam height is much larger than it, and Bowen ratio needs to be determined accurately over wet surface, while air temperature, air pressure and aerodynamic roughness length are not sensitive for HLAS. According to the observations mentioned above, LAS can measure surface fluxes both over homogeneous and heterogeneous surfaces.

Disjunctive.Question: In the context of surface flux measurements, is the eddy covariance system more reliable, or does the large aperture scintillometer offer better coverage?
For data assimilation strategies in improving water and heat flux estimates, is adjusting soil temperature or soil moisture more effective?

Concept Completion.Answer: air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed, wind direction, atmospheric pressure, precipitation, four-component radiation, infrared surface temperature, soil temperature and moisture at multiple depths, soil heat flux

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when using ground measurements for upscaling water and heat flux observations to a regional scale?
Example.Answer: A challenge is the insufficient monitoring network for ground measurements, which limits the ability to achieve global coverage. This necessitates the development of techniques such as data assimilation to combine observations with land surface models to improve predictions and scale observations from patch to regional levels.

Feature Specification.Question: What features of surface flux measurements make large aperture scintillometers advantageous over traditional methods?
Feature Specification.Answer: larger spatial scales, hundreds of meters to several kilometers, aligns with satellite pixel scales, aligns with grid scales of numerical weather prediction and climate models, more representative ground-truthing tool

Definition.Question: How do researchers determine the aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) over different land surfaces, and why is it important?
Definition.Answer: The aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is determined using wind profile measurements and is crucial for surface flux estimations in remote sensing and land surface models. It describes the surface's roughness characteristics, which influence wind turbulence. Researchers relate z0m to land surface properties like vegetation height and leaf area index and use footprint models to account for directional characteristics over heterogeneous surfaces.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods using automatic weather stations compare to those utilizing large aperture scintillometers in terms of spatial coverage and accuracy for measuring surface fluxes?
Comparison.Answer: Automatic weather stations provide relatively accurate data at the patch scale but are limited in spatial coverage, requiring upscaling for regional analysis. Large aperture scintillometers, on the other hand, measure surface fluxes over much larger areas (500 m to 10 km), making them suitable for regional-scale observations. However, LAS requires careful consideration of environmental factors like wind speed and beam height for accuracy.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data assimilation strategies when adjusting soil temperature compared to soil moisture in improving water and heat flux estimates?
Comparison.Answer: Data assimilation strategies that adjust soil temperature focus on improving the estimation of water and heat fluxes by aligning soil temperature data, while those adjusting soil moisture aim to refine the estimates by modifying soil moisture levels. Soil moisture adjustments (strategy 2) have been found to be superior in improving estimates compared to soil temperature adjustments (strategy 1) when using the same optimization algorithm.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do aerodynamic roughness length calculations differ when using wind profile measurements compared to parameterizations based on land surface properties?
Comparison.Answer: Aerodynamic roughness length is traditionally calculated using wind profile measurements via the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory, which can be challenging for regional scales. Parameterizations based on land surface properties, such as vegetation height and leaf area index, offer an alternative by relating roughness length to these characteristics, providing a heuristic approach for model parameterizations over heterogeneous surfaces.

Interpretation.Question: How might the integration of remote sensing technologies with ground-based measurements improve the accuracy of water and heat flux estimations at different scales?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of remote sensing with ground-based measurements provides opportunities to upscale observations from patch to regional scales, allowing for more accurate monitoring of water and heat fluxes. Ground measurements offer accuracy at the patch scale, while remote sensing can capture land surface information at regional scales. This combination helps overcome the limitations of insufficient global coverage of ground measurements.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can data assimilation techniques enhance the predictive capabilities of land surface models in terms of estimating surface temperature and fluxes?
Interpretation.Answer: Data assimilation techniques improve predictions by integrating observational data with model outputs, reducing uncertainties in land surface models. Adjusting soil temperature and moisture through data assimilation strategies, like those using EnKF and SCE-UA algorithms, can significantly enhance estimates of surface temperature and water and heat fluxes, as validated by reductions in RMSE values in specific case studies.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges are associated with applying Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) to large aperture scintillometer (LAS) data, and how can these challenges be addressed?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges in applying MOST to LAS data include the influence of surface type, flatness, and weather conditions, which can deviate from ideal assumptions. The applicability of MOST can be affected by large-scale eddy movements and atmospheric turbulence. To address these challenges, new methods like factor analysis and temperature structure parameter methods have been developed to assess the suitability of MOST in practical applications.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges of expanding monitoring networks for ground measurements to achieve global coverage?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges in expanding monitoring networks for ground measurements stem from the limited spatial coverage that current networks provide. Ground measurements are accurate at a patch scale but insufficient for global coverage, necessitating the need to upscale observations from the patch to the regional or global scale. Additionally, uncertainties within model parameters, structures, and forcing data further complicate the expansion and application of land surface models.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it necessary to develop techniques combining land surface models with different types of observations?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Developing techniques that combine land surface models with different types of observations is necessary due to the uncertainties and inaccuracies that can arise from the model parameters, structures, and forcing data. These uncertainties adversely affect the predictions of water and heat fluxes and hinder the development and application of land surface models. By integrating various observations, such as remote sensing data, these techniques can significantly improve the accuracy and reliability of model predictions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the variation in aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) over different land surfaces, and how does it impact surface flux estimations?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The variation in aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) over different land surfaces is primarily caused by the heterogeneity in the size and spatial distribution of roughness elements, such as vegetation and obstacles. This variation impacts surface flux estimations as z0m is a critical factor in determining the surface's roughness characteristics. Accurate estimation of z0m is essential for reliable surface flux predictions, especially in remote sensing and land surface models, as it influences wind turbulence and energy exchange processes.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential effects of integrating remote sensing data with ground-based measurements on the accuracy of water and heat flux estimations?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating remote sensing data with ground-based measurements can improve the accuracy of water and heat flux estimations by providing wider spatial coverage and complementing the precise but localized ground measurements. This integration can help in upscaling observations from patch to regional scale, thus reducing the uncertainties associated with land model outputs due to limited monitoring network coverage.

Causal Consequence.Question: What consequences might arise from the directional dependence of aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) on the estimation of surface fluxes over heterogeneous land surfaces?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The directional dependence of aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) can lead to variability in surface flux estimations over heterogeneous land surfaces. This is because z0m varies due to the heterogeneity in the size and spatial distribution of roughness elements, which can affect the accuracy of remote sensing algorithms and land surface models that rely on z0m as a parameter for estimating surface fluxes.

Causal Consequence.Question: What outcomes could result from applying the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) under varying atmospheric stability conditions in the context of large aperture scintillometer (LAS) observations?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Applying the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) under varying atmospheric stability conditions can significantly affect the applicability and accuracy of LAS observations. Unstable conditions with large-scale eddies and developed atmospheric turbulence can impact the theory's applicability. Establishing new methods to judge MOST's applicability, such as factor analysis and temperature structure parameter method, can help ensure reliable estimations of sensible heat flux in these varying conditions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the main objectives for collecting multi-scale surface flux and meteorological data over agricultural areas using an automatic weather station?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The main objectives are to provide accurate estimation of water and heat fluxes crucial to climate change research, water resource planning and management, and water-saving agriculture applications. This data aids in understanding and improving land surface model predictions by integrating with data assimilation techniques.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedures involved in ensuring the quality and reliability of data collected from automatic weather stations for surface flux measurements?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedures include ensuring the collection of 144 data entries per day with a 10-minute interval, marking missing data with -6999, removing duplicate records, deleting data that is physically unreasonable or out of instrument range, and standardizing the date and time format in a single column.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can data assimilation techniques be applied to improve land surface model predictions using remote sensing observations?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Data assimilation techniques can be applied by developing a system that includes a model operator for calculating diurnal variations, an observation operator for predicting surface temperature from model state variables, and an optimization scheme for optimizing state variables. Two strategies involve adjusting soil temperature or soil moisture using optimization algorithms like EnKF and SCE-UA.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies are used to calculate the aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) over heterogeneous surfaces, and how can these be parameterized for use in remote sensing models?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Methodologies involve the use of analytical footprint models to calculate z0m over different surfaces, analyzing directional characteristics, and relating z0m to roughness element characteristics like vegetation height and leaf area index. A heuristic parameterization of z0m is developed as a reference for model parameterizations.

Enablement.Question: What data collection techniques enable the accurate measurement of water and heat fluxes at a regional scale, and how can these techniques be integrated with remote sensing methods?
Enablement.Answer: Ground measurements are accurate at the patch scale, but the need to upscale observations for regional coverage can be met by integrating with remote sensing, which accurately acquires land surface information at a regional scale. Techniques like data assimilation, which combine land surface models with observations, and the use of large aperture scintillometers can help improve these measurements.

Enablement.Question: How can the challenges of insufficient ground measurement networks for global coverage be addressed to enhance the accuracy of surface flux estimations?
Enablement.Answer: To address the challenge of insufficient ground measurement networks, developing techniques that combine land surface models with various observations, such as data assimilation using MODIS LST products with the Common Land Model, can help improve predictions. Additionally, the use of large aperture scintillometers (LAS) provides regional scale measurements that can optimize and validate remote sensing models.

Enablement.Question: What factors enable the effective parameterization of aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) for use in remote sensing and land surface models?
Enablement.Answer: Effective parameterization of aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) involves relating z0m to roughness element characteristics like vegetation height and leaf area index, as wind turbulence is controlled by these elements. The variation of z0m across different surfaces and its direction-dependent nature due to heterogeneous roughness elements must be considered for accurate parameterization.

Expectation.Question: Why might ground measurement networks be insufficient for global coverage of water and heat fluxes, and what expectations could be placed on remote sensing methods to address this gap?
Expectation.Answer: Ground measurement networks are often limited in spatial coverage and are primarily effective at the patch scale. Remote sensing methods are expected to provide accurate land surface information at a regional scale, offering new opportunities to monitor water and heat fluxes more broadly.

Expectation.Question: Why might large aperture scintillometer (LAS) data be expected to provide more reliable surface flux measurements compared to traditional methods, and what are the anticipated challenges in applying the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) in this context?
Expectation.Answer: LAS data is anticipated to offer more reliable surface flux measurements over larger scales (500 m to 10 km) than traditional methods, whose spatial representativeness is limited. However, challenges such as the applicability of MOST under varying atmospheric conditions and the need for accurate stability function formulations remain significant.

Request/Directive.Question: Please provide an overview of the techniques used to measure sensible heat flux on larger scales and the adaptability of these methods to different surface types.
Request/Directive.Answer: Large aperture scintillometers (LAS) have become popular for measuring sensible heat flux on scales from 500 m to 10 km, offering an advantage over traditional methods like the eddy covariance system. LAS measurements are based on Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory and can serve as relative ground truth for remote sensing and numerical models. Sensitivity analyses indicate that beam height and wind speed are critical factors, while air temperature, pressure, and roughness length are less sensitive. LAS can measure fluxes over both homogeneous and heterogeneous surfaces.
